chapter.title: Getting started
chapter.para: Learning a new framework is not always straight forward. In this section, we (the Spring DM team) tried to provide, what we think is, an easy to follow guide in starting with Spring Dynamic Modules. Of course, feel free to create your own learning 'path' as you see fit and, if possible, please report to use any improvements to the documentation that can help others.

section.title: First Steps
section.para: As explained in , Spring Dynamic Modules provides integration between Spring framework and OSGi. Thus, it is important to become acquainted with both of these frameworks (libraries or environments depending on how you want to name them). Throughout the Spring DM documentation, each section provides links to resources relevant however, it is best to become yourself familiar with these topics.

section.title: Knowing Spring
section.para: Spring DM uses heavily Spring framework's core functionalty, such as the IoC container, resource abstract or AOP infrastructure. While it is not important to know the Spring APIs, understanding the concepts behind them is. At a minimum, the idea behind IoC should be familiar. These being said, the more knowledge one has about the Spring, the faster she will pick Spring Dynamic Modules.

Besides the very comprehensive (and sometimes disarming) documentation that explains into details the Spring Framework, there are a lot of articles, blog entries and books on the matter - take a look at the Spring framework home page for more information.
In general, this should be the starting point for OSGi (or Eclipse plugin) developers wanting to try Spring DM.

section.title: Trying Out The Samples
section.para: Since 1.2.0 M2, the Spring DM bundles symbolic names have been aligned with Spring's 2.5.6+. Thus the prefix org.springframework.bundle.osgi has been changed to org.springframework.osgi; for example Spring DM extender symbolic name was changed from org.springframework.bundle.osgi.extender to org.springframework.osgi.extender (notice the missing bundle word). Additionally, the documentation has been updated to reflect Spring 2.5.6+ symbolic names.
